JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, MARYLAND, NOVEMBER 17. 1967

University Waiting For S.C.
Before Deciding Vic's Case
Ross Jones, Secretary of the University, says that the
Hopkins is waiting to speak with the Student Council
before issuing a policy statement on the alledged discrimination at the Marylander Barber Shop.
Jones said that he had "tried to contact Bruce Ledig,"
Student Council President. "If Ledig would ever respond
to me I would ask him and Victor Dates to go to the •
shop and see what the situation is."
Last year the Student Council took part in the barber shop discrimination case. Therefore, Jones wants to
be sure that the Council is satisfied before he makes a
formal public statement.
"Really," he said, "there is no problem. According to
what I've been able to determine, he is not chargine prices
which tend to keep Negroes out of the shop." However,
he wants Ledig to go and talk with Victor the barber. If
the Council is satisfied that there has been no discrimination, the University will issue a public statement.
The controversy was sparked by a sign in the shop
which advised that "kinky" hair could not be cut for less
than three dollars. Regular haircuts cost two dollars. The
sign was recently removed, when Victor DeRuggiero,
proprietor of the shop, heard that the University objected. Razor cuts for Negroes now cost three dollars while
a regular hair cut costs two dollars for anyone.
Victor says that the price hike for Negroes is due to
the fact that their hair is harder to cut than is Caucasians' hair. He insists that he is not descriminatory.
"Victor welcomes everyone!" says Victor. He added that
he had never had a Negro ask for a razor cut in his shop,
and therefore, had never charged three dollars.
Arnold Rausenberger, a barber in the Levering Hall
shop, said that cutting Negroes' hair presented no special
problems. He added that he couldn't understand why
Victor would charge extra for a razor cut of curly hair.
Ledig said that the Student Council probably would
do something about the barber shop incident. As yet,
however, he was not familiar with the facts. "What has
gone on around there?" he asked.

Freshmen Descend To New Depths
As Liquor Flows In Carrel Party
By DICK CRAMER
The administration has decided to take an unequivocal stand in regard to a party thrown in the study carrels
beneath the freshmen dormitories.
Some freshman decided that the newly opened study
room would be the perfect site for a small party. As the
room can be entered only with the use of a room key
and since not many dormitory residents study on Saturday, they had no fear of being disturbed. Therefore, they
stocked the room and gave it a small house-warming.
The room has been adequately soundproofed and the
party was never discovered. The girls in attendance, of
course, left before one o'clock and the gathering was
ended without incident. However, no one was overcautious about leaving traces behind.
The next day, beer bottles and cans were found
strewn about the rdom. One of the frosted glass partitions which separate the carrels was smashed. The administration swung into action with a concentrated investigatory program.
Mrs. Van Norman, upon hearing the news, embarked
on a tour of the disaster area. Later in the day, Robert
P. Bilgrave, Director of Student Affairs, was seen inspecting the premises.
Mrs. Van Norman commented, "It's a very unusual
place for this to happen. Most people are looking for a
quiet place to study." As yet, she has taken no definitive
• action. According to her, it is not within her province to
do so. "It's the responsibility of the D.S.R.C. and the
Plant Manager's Office," she said. "I really have very
little to do with it."
Mr. Wesley Taylor, Plant Manager, said that, as yet, he
has "not talked to anyone about it." He added that the
matter was the responsibility of Mrs. Van Norman and
and the D.S.R.C.
Henry Yang, President of the D.S.R.C. said, "I
really don't know too much about it." When asked under
whose jurisdiction the incident fell, he replied, "It's
really only the responsibility of the D.S.R.C."
Colonel Robert Serena, Head Resident Dorm Master,
minced no words on the incident. "See Mr. Bilgrave," he
said. "He's handling it". Mr. Bilgrave could not be reached for comment.

Vietnam War Threatens Cutbacks
In Government Grants To Hopkins
By BOB SLOAN
EDITOR'S NOTE: This is the second of a series concerning the financial shortages at Hopkins.
Cutbacks in Federal spending for higher education due
to the Vietnam War threaten to aggravate Hopkins' financial problem.
Government funds to Hopkins, which made up 52%
of the current revenues for 1966-67, may be substantially reduced in the near future if the freeze on federal
aid continues. A primary cause of the freeze is the enormous cost of the war in Vietnam. Smaller, lower-rated
schools have already felt the effects of the cutbacks, but
Hopkins as yet has only felt the pinch slightly.
However, if the war drags on the shortage of funds
going to Hopkins will be acute. If replacement funds cannot be found the University "will have no other choice"
than to make cutbacks says Bruce J. Partridge, VicePresident for the Administration. He added that because
government money makes up so large a portion of the
budget, this contraction will be the only solution.
Though Government money goes for government
projects, the funds result in a portion of professorial
salaries, the addition of graduate students, and the purchase of equipment for research. These side benefits of
the federal funds for individual research add substantially
to the resources of the University.
When a professor applies for a grant to do individual
research, the request must first be approved by the
University with respect to its cost and the number of
hours involved. If the University approves the project,
the request goes to the government board kir approval.
If, for example, the professor will spend half his time
for research, the government will pay half of his normal
salary. Graduate students are hired and the cost they incur is shared by the University and government; the same
holds for purchased equipment.

Housemaster's Report Scores
Food Service Administration

Doyle Smith; a dormitory housemaster, submitted a
report two weeks ago, highly critical of the administration of the food service.
The report, submitted to Howard LaShaw, director of
the dormitory Food Service, concluded that the Food
Service "should be run on a cash basis." Smith stated
that "the only way to cut out the flab" is to run the
Food Service on a competitive basis.
Smith surveyed dormitory residents in order to compile his report. The report was initiated by request of the
Plant Manager's Office.
The report criticized the time scheduling of the cafeteria, as well as the machinery involved in the operation
of the food service.
A particular target of Smith's report was a "young
undergraduate" employed by the cafeteria. Besides being
"unclean, flippant and generally incompetent" as Smith
implied that most of the student help were, he distastefully noticed the undergraduate's habit of "picking his
nose and running his fingers through his hair and then
serving you."
In the survey which Smith conducted, 27 floors in the
Freshman houses were polled. Some "novelties" which
Smith discovered in reviewing the complaints included a
freshman finding a fly "cooked into his roll."
Four floors of freshman complained about finding
hair in their food. Ten floors noted the quantity of dirty
dishes. While there was unanimous sentiment that food
in the cafeteria was poor, twelve floors of freshman indicated that they just couldn't get enough of it.
Smith concluded that "the administration must come
to grips with the food problem, and it is their responsibility to do whatever is needed to repair defects in the
Food Service. The handicap of budgets is the Plant Manager's office doing, not the students."
Smith stated that "it should be made clear that we expect action, prompt and decisive actions."

Hopkins Leads In The Developing
Of New Drug To Treat Blood Clots

Hieronimous Exhibit Provokes
Charges Of Religious Blasphemy

Dr. Henry Wagner and Dr. Donald Tow, researchers at
the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, will be among
the leading participants in the test of urokinase, a new
drug for the effective treatment of arterial thrombosis.
Urokinase,so named because it is derived from human
urine, is not designed for the prevention of arterial
thrombosis, but instead it will be used to dissolve clots
in the arteries.
Both Dr. Wagner and Dr. Tow hope that this drug will
be effective in the correction of such medical disorders
as pulmonary embolism and mycardal infarctions.
Urokinase will enable doctors to dissolve blood clots
in a matter of hours, a process which presently takes up
to three weeks With present treatment patients often
die or are seriously disabled.
Neither Hopkins' doctors have spent all their time on
urine. Working concurrently they have developed an
"isotope scanning system," which allows them to see
what affect the drug is having. This technique promises
many other possibilities, yet to be examined.
Urokinase likewise enables the development of new
techniques in blood transfusion. "In fact," states Dr.
Tibor Greenwalt, medical director of the American
National Red Cross,"it is now old-fashioned to use whole
blood for transfusions."
He added that it is now possible to take only the
plasma from the blood and return the remaining components of the blood to the body. This technique will aid
in alleviating the problem caused by a shortage' of available blood in today's hospitals.
In practice, this means that as much as one liter ot
plasma a week could be removed from a healthy donor
without any ill effects.
This ability to transfuse large quantities of blood
means that parents of a child suffering from leukemia
might "donate just the platelets in their blood up to two
or three times a week."
Platelet transfusions are used to control bleeding in
leukemia.
Urokinase and other new techniques for the treatment of blood disorders, were outlined by the panel of
experts during the briefing of"New Horizons in Science
sponsored by the Washington University in St. Louis
and The Council for the Advancement of Science Writing.

by DENNIS ESTIS
Several persons, including faculty wives, have charged
that the art exhibit of Robert Hieronimus, 'currently
being shown at Levering Hall, is "irreverent".
Those people, both in the Hopkins community and in
the City, have been shocked by the artists' portrayal of
of the Christ figure and several other symbols which he
employs.
Dr. Chester Wickwire, Director of Levering Hall, expressed the opinion that these charges were minor in
nature. Dr. Wickwire felt that the comments made were
typical reactions one "might expect from persons not
accustomed to this kind of art".
"Hieronimus is hot attempting to be irreverent," said
Wickwire, "but he feels that America, and not himself,
has desecrated these symbols."
In reply to the charges. Hieronimus said that he also
had some complaints. He placed the primary blame on
the present leaders of our nation in every field of endeavor, including religion. "Our religious leaders have not
listened to the needs of the generation. The symbols are
not a slap at all. Man needs God, but not in a traditional
sense."
Dr. Wickwire feels that the exhibit is "very worthwhile", and believes that it has "livened things up."
The exhibit features a sculpture of a dummy which is
crucified on a wooden cross. The dummy is decorated
with symbols of American materialism such as Coke buttons,and dollar signs. The exhibit also includes paintings,
pen drawings, and a sculpture which revolves on a turntable.
Hieronimus is also involved in other activities. He goes
to the Maryland Institute and used to teach in public
schools in Baltimore County. He painted the front of
the new Black Jack night club on Lafayette Avenue,and
he spends his spare time painting bodies on Howard
Street. He is most noted on campus for his multicolored
"symbolic Volkswagen" and his poster advertising the
"Mothers of Invention" concert.
Many of the works on display at the exhibit can be
purchased from the author at a nominal fee. There are
certain paintings which cost as much as $1000.
Immediately at the close of the Hieronimus show,an
exhibit of ceramic pieces will be displayed, along with
works by Mrs. Raya Bueding.

The Grass, Somewhere, Is Greener
In a recent report to the Plant Manager's Office, freshman housemaster, past DSRC president and veteran dorm dweller Doyle Smith
informed Wesley Taylor that not only was the food served in the
dormitories of exceptionally poor quality, but that organizational
_aspects of the food service's management makes dining there an unattractive and harrasing ordeal.
The report is the most recent evidence of a growing dissatisfaction directed against the very services dorm residents hope to receive
for the $900 each pays to the university annually. Despite the recent
outlay of money for unseen improvements, and compared to many
universities throughout the nation who are rapidly expanding their
dormitory facilities with new and modern structures, Hopkins students are resigned to living in two-tone cinder block cell blocks.
Granted, Hopkins cannot suddenly refurbish or build new dorms at
the moment, but it can furnish the dormitory diner with more nutritious and attractive meals.
Among the complaints listed in Smith's report(A compilation of
freshman grievances) were: too much starch, too small poultry, too
little food, dirty utensils, no variety or choice in any one meal,
greasy food, little fruit, hair and flies (ad nauseum) in food, badly
prepared desserts,etc., etc ...There is no excuse for these conditions
to continue. One need only go as close by as Notre Dame to see how
well some students are able to eat.
Housemaster Smith comes to the conclusion that the food service should henceforth be run on a cash basis, which would force it
to become more competitive — that is, if better food were offered,
more students would patronize the dining room; if a poor meal were
served, students could eat elsewhere and only the food service would
lose out.
We strongly recommend that the Plant Manager's Office look into
such a proposition by requesting bids from competing food services,
including the largest and most popular service, which, incidentally,
feeds the hungry mouths at Goucher and Notre Dame. To have a dormitory with good enough food and organization to attract enough
dorm students to eat there on a cash basis would entail a considerably
larger budget for food on the part of the Plant Manager. But the
money which many dorm residents now lose by missing meals breakfasts when they sleep late, lunches when they have classes, din- _
ner when they are away - Or parents come to town - would perhaps make up for the more expensive meals served on a cash basis.
How far more democratic it would be to pay for the mealswhich you
are here to eat and which you want to eat, rather than paying for the
liver you do not eat and the stone-hard cake you cannot digest.
At a recent ODK meeting, Hopkins Plant Manager Wesley Taylor
explained that he had once received bids from several food services,
and the present management had underbid all others. He also expressed his faith in the product it offers the dorm students at dinner
time. Mr. Taylor is also the gentleman, reliable sources have told us,
who recently suggested that the Kosher Dining Room lower its quality of food if it wants to lower its prices. Such a truism we do not
dispute, but we certainly hope he has not lowered the quality of
food in the dormitory for this reason when we have been told by
Doyle Smith that students there would prefer paying slightly more if
they could be assured of a corresponding improvement in their
meals.
We feel certain that if the concerned parties in the administration
devoted their time to trying to find a more effective and appetizing
mean of feeding the dorm students rather than quieting and calming incipient food protests, then perhaps a solution to the problem
could be found. But in case the Plant Manager is not sensitive to the
request of Doyle Smith and other students, then dorm residents
may well find last year's student council president Bill Reinsch's
suggestion the most effective - -dump an entire dinner on the steps
of Homewood House.

University Waiting For S.C.
Before Deciding Vic's Case
Ross Jones, Secretary of the University, says that the
Hopkins is waiting to speak with the Student Council
before issuing a policy statement on the alledged discrimination at the Marylander Barber Shop.
Jones said that he had "tried to contact Bruce Ledig,"
Student Council President. "If Ledig would ever respond
to me I would ask him and Victor Dates to go to the •
shop and see what the situation is."
Last year the Student Council took part in the barber shop discrimination case. Therefore, Jones wants to
be sure that the Council is satisfied before he makes a
formal public statement.
"Really," he said, "there is no problem. According to
what I've been able to determine, he is not chargine prices
which tend to keep Negroes out of the shop." However,
he wants Ledig to go and talk with Victor the barber. If
the Council is satisfied that there has been no discrimination, the University will issue a public statement.
The controversy was sparked by a sign in the shop
which advised that "kinky" hair could not be cut for less
than three dollars. Regular haircuts cost two dollars. The
sign was recently removed, when Victor DeRuggiero,
proprietor of the shop, heard that the University objected. Razor cuts for Negroes now cost three dollars while
a regular hair cut costs two dollars for anyone.
Victor says that the price hike for Negroes is due to
the fact that their hair is harder to cut than is Caucasians' hair. He insists that he is not descriminatory.
"Victor welcomes everyone!" says Victor. He added that
he had never had a Negro ask for a razor cut in his shop,

Dr. Henry Wagner and Dr. Donald Tow, researchers at
the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, will be among
the leading participants in the test of urokinase, a new
drug for the effective treatment of arterial thrombosis.
Urokinase,so named because it is derived from human
urine, is not designed for the prevention of arterial
thrombosis, but instead it will be used to dissolve clots
in the arteries.
Both Dr. Wagner and Dr. Tow hope that this drug will
be effective in the correction of such medical disorders
as pulmonary embolism and mycardal infarctions.
Urokinase will enable doctors to dissolve blood clots
in a matter of hours, a process which presently takes up
to three weeks With present treatment patients often
die or are seriously disabled.
Neither Hopkins' doctors have spent all their time on
urine. Working concurrently they have developed an
"isotope scanning system," which allows them to see
what affect the drug is having. This technique promises
many other possibilities, yet to be examined.
Urokinase likewise enables the development of new
techniques in blood transfusion. "In fact," states Dr.
Tibor Greenwalt, medical director of the American
National Red Cross,"it is now old-fashioned to use whole
blood for transfusions."
He added that it is now possible to take only the
plasma from the blood and return the remaining components of the blood to the body. This technique will aid
in alleviating the problem caused by a shortage' of available blood in today's hospitals.
In practice, this means that as much as one liter ot
plasma a week could be removed from a healthy donor
without any ill effects.
This ability to transfuse large quantities of blood
means that parents of a child suffering from leukemia
might "donate just the platelets in their blood up to two
or three times a week."
Platelet transfusions are used to control bleeding in
leukemia.

In a recent report to the Plant Manager's Office, freshman housemaster, past DSRC president and veteran dorm dweller Doyle Smith
informed Wesley Taylor that not only was the food served in the
dormitories of exceptionally poor quality, but that organizational
_aspects of the food service's management makes dining there an unattractive and harrasing ordeal.
The report is the most recent evidence of a growing dissatisfaction directed against the very services dorm residents hope to receive
for the $900 each pays to the university annually. Despite the recent
outlay of money for unseen improvements, and compared to many
universities throughout the nation who are rapidly expanding their
dormitory facilities with new and modern structures, Hopkins students are resigned to living in two-tone cinder block cell blocks.
Granted, Hopkins cannot suddenly refurbish or build new dorms at
the moment, but it can furnish the dormitory diner with more nutritious and attractive meals.
Among the complaints listed in Smith's report(A compilation of
freshman grievances) were: too much starch, too small poultry, too
little food, dirty utensils, no variety or choice in any one meal,
greasy food, little fruit, hair and flies (ad nauseum) in food, badly
prepared desserts,etc., etc ...There is no excuse for these conditions
to continue. One need only go as close by as Notre Dame to see how
well some students are able to eat.
Housemaster Smith comes to the conclusion that the food service should henceforth be run on a cash basis, which would force it
to become more competitive — that is, if better food were offered,
more students would patronize the dining room; if a poor meal were
served, students could eat elsewhere and only the food service would
lose out.
We strongly recommend that the Plant Manager's Office look into
such a proposition by requesting bids from competing food services,
including the largest and most popular service, which, incidentally,
feeds the hungry mouths at Goucher and Notre Dame. To have a dormitory with good enough food and organization to attract enough
dorm students to eat there on a cash basis would entail a considerably
larger budget for food on the part of the Plant Manager. But the
money which many dorm residents now lose by missing meals breakfasts when they sleep late, lunches when they have classes, din- _
ner when they are away - Or parents come to town - would perhaps make up for the more expensive meals served on a cash basis.
How far more democratic it would be to pay for the mealswhich you
are here to eat and which you want to eat, rather than paying for the
liver you do not eat and the stone-hard cake you cannot digest.

explained that he had once received bids from several food services,

food in the dormitory for this reason when we have been told by
Doyle Smith that students there would prefer paying slightly more if
they could be assured of a corresponding improvement in their
meals.

devoted their time to trying to find a more effective and appetizing
mean of feeding the dorm students rather than quieting and calming incipient food protests, then perhaps a solution to the problem

request of Doyle Smith and other students, then dorm residents
may well find last year's student council president Bill Reinsch's
suggestion the most effective - -dump an entire dinner on the steps
of Homewood House.
